title: 111_hr2991
content: The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, or performance bonds by a principal, with certain conditions. The Act allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, or performance bonds by a principal, with certain conditions. An eligible small business concern may require a bond to bid on a contract, and if unable to obtain it on reasonable terms without a guarantee, the Secretary may provide one. There must be a reasonable expectation of performance and the bond terms should be reasonable considering the risks involved. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against loss from avoiding a breach of a guaranteed bond, provided that a breach was imminent and approval was obtained. The Secretary may indemnify a surety for avoiding a bond breach if imminent and approved. Payment by the Secretary cannot exceed 10% of the contract price unless a greater amount is deemed necessary and reasonable. The Secretary cannot pay the surety more than the guaranteed share of the bond. The Secretary may reimburse a surety for up to 90% of the loss incurred, not exceeding the guaranteed share of the bond. The reimbursement shall not result in any duplicate payments and will be determined based on specific conditions outlined in the agreement. The Secretary may reimburse a surety for up to 90% of the loss incurred under a guarantee or agreement, with exceptions for fraud, breach of terms, or violation of regulations. Regulations may be established by the Secretary. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties regarding underwriting, claim practices, and loss ratios. The Secretary can also adopt a procedure for reimbursing sureties for paid losses, with subsequent adjustments. Sureties are required to make reports to the Secretary. The Secretary requires participating sureties to make reports and allows audits of their documents. Sureties are audited at least once every three years. The Secretary administers this subsection prudently and economically. The Secretary administers the subsection prudently and economically, establishing fees for small businesses and premiums for sureties. A state program may be established for up to 5 states to carry out activities related to issuing guarantees. The Secretary oversees guarantee issuance activities and surety assistance for small businesses. States in the program must meet prescribed standards and submit annual reports on their administered programs. States in the program must meet prescribed standards and submit annual reports on their administered programs, including the number of guarantees provided and the participation of eligible small business concerns. Definitions for terms like bid bond are also provided in the subsection. The Secretary oversees guarantee issuance activities and surety assistance for small businesses, including eligibility criteria for small business concerns such as those owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals or service-disabled veterans. The curr_chunk discusses small business concerns eligible for surety assistance, including those owned by service-disabled veterans, qualified HUBZone small businesses, and women-owned small businesses. The term 'obligee' is defined as the person requesting bids for a contract. The curr_chunk defines payment bond as a bond ensuring payment to persons under contract with the principal, and performance bond as a bond ensuring completion of the contract by the principal. The curr_chunk defines performance bond as a bond ensuring completion of a contract by the principal, prime contractor as the contracted person, and principal as the person primarily liable for contract completion or payments. The curr_chunk defines terms such as Secretary, subcontractor, and surety in relation to contract performance and obligations. The curr_chunk explains the obligations of a surety under bid, performance, and payment bonds in the event of a breach by the principal. The curr_chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations to the Secretary for activities under a specific subsection, totaling $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2010 through 2014. SEC. 3 amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, US Code to include any mode of transportation. SEC. 4 amends Section 332(d) by removing specific entities.
